english_translation: Narrated from Qabisah ibn Uqbah, who said: I heard Sufyan saying: My father was a merchant, and the hadith that I take from him does not please him.

narrators.name: Qabisah ibn Uqbah
narrators.full_name: Qabisah ibn Uqbah ibn Farqad al-Thaqafi

narrators.name: Sufyan
narrators.full_name: Sufyan ibn Sa'id ibn Masruq al-Thawri

chainIssues: Sufyan al-Thawri is known for tadlis (Category 2), but uses the direct transmission term 'samiʿtu' here, which is strongest evidence of direct hearing. This chain is reliable.

potential_issues.issue: Sufyan al-Thawri is classified as a mudallis (Category 2 - mild form), though he is highly reliable overall
potential_issues.impact: The explicit use of 'samiʿtu' (I heard) by Qabisah from Sufyan eliminates any tadlis concerns here. The direct transmission term demonstrates explicit hearing.

Topics: Character description of Sufyan al-Thawri
Sufyan's father's profession and business orientation
Hadith scholars' diverse family backgrounds

english_translation: Narrated from Khalaf ibn Tammim, who said: I heard Sufyan al-Thawri saying: I found my heart is comforted in Mecca and Medina, with strangers who are people with houses and simple garments.

narrators.name: Khalaf ibn Tammim
narrators.full_name: Khalaf ibn Tammim ibn Zayd

narrators.name: Sufyan al-Thawri
narrators.full_name: Sufyan ibn Sa'id ibn Masruq al-Thawri

chainIssues: Khalaf ibn Tammim is Saduq (reliable but not of highest grade). Sufyan al-Thawri uses 'samiʿtu' (I heard) which eliminates tadlis concerns despite his mudallis classification.

potential_issues.issue: Khalaf ibn Tammim is Saduq, not among the highest category of narrators, which is lower than ideal
potential_issues.impact: Khalaf is generally trustworthy but his grade is below Thiqah. However, the content being a saying (maqtu') of Sufyan is acceptable with this chain.

potential_issues.issue: Sufyan al-Thawri is classified as mudallis (Category 2)
potential_issues.impact: The explicit use of 'samiʿtu' (I heard) by Khalaf eliminates any concern about indirect transmission. Direct hearing is established.

Topics: Spiritual comfort of Sufyan al-Thawri in the sacred cities
Preference for simple living over material wealth
The sanctity of Mecca and Medina as places of spiritual tranquility

english_translation: Narrated from Qabisah ibn Uqbah, who said: An unknown man informed me from Sufyan saying: Seek knowledge, and when you have learned it, preserve it, and when you have preserved it, act upon it, and when you have acted upon it, spread it.

narrators.name: Qabisah ibn Uqbah
narrators.full_name: Qabisah ibn Uqbah ibn Farqad al-Thaqafi

narrators.name: Unknown man
narrators.full_name: Unknown man (راجل/رجل غير معروف)

narrators.name: Sufyan
narrators.full_name: Sufyan ibn Sa'id ibn Masruq al-Thawri

chainIssues: Critical: Unknown narrator (rajul) with majhul al-ayn status breaks the chain reliability. Sufyan al-Thawri uses 'an' (from) which is ambiguous, though he is generally reliable. The anonymous narrator is the major problem.

potential_issues.issue: An unnamed man (majhul al-ayn) serves as an intermediate narrator between Qabisah and Sufyan
potential_issues.impact: This significantly weakens the chain. A narrator known only as 'a man' with no identifying information is a critical gap in the isnad. The entire chain becomes questionable due to this unnamed link.

potential_issues.issue: Sufyan al-Thawri uses 'an' (from) rather than samiʿtu (I heard)
potential_issues.impact: Although Sufyan is highly reliable, the use of 'an' introduces ambiguity. Combined with the unknown narrator above, this further compromises chain integrity.

Topics: Method of seeking and preserving knowledge
Stages of knowledge acquisition and application
Responsibility to spread knowledge to others

english_translation: Narrated from Bakkar, who said: Sufyan al-Thawri used to say frequently: O Allah, grant salvation, grant salvation.

narrators.name: Bakkar
narrators.full_name: Bakkar ibn Qutaybah al-Lakhmi

narrators.name: Sufyan al-Thawri
narrators.full_name: Sufyan ibn Sa'id ibn Masruq al-Thawri

chainIssues: Bakkar ibn Qutaybah is Saduq (moderately reliable). The transmission term 'qala' (he said) indicates reported speech rather than direct hearing, though this is acceptable for biographical statements.

potential_issues.issue: Bakkar ibn Qutaybah is Saduq, not among the highest grades
potential_issues.impact: While Saduq is generally acceptable, this is lower than Thiqah. For a biographical statement about Sufyan's frequent supplication, this is minimally acceptable.

Topics: Sufyan al-Thawri's personal supplications and devotion
Seeking safety and salvation from Allah
The piety and constant remembrance of Allah by early scholars

english_translation: Narrated by Yahya ibn Abi Bukair, who said: I heard Shu'bah saying: Whatever Sufyan narrated to me from al-Suddi, when I asked him about it, it was exactly as he narrated it to me. He continued: People used to think that Sufyan took gifts from rulers once, then stopped accepting anything from anyone. He used to trade in Yemen and distribute what he had among his brothers who would trade with it for him. He would meet them at the season (of hajj) every year and settle accounts with them, taking the profit. He had about two hundred dinars. He had a son, and there was nothing more beloved to him than that son. He wished to have a son. When his son died, after his death, he made his sister and her children his heirs, not his brother al-Mubarak ibn Sa'id. When Sufyan was sought (by the authorities), he fled to Mecca. The Caliph al-Mahdi wrote to Muhammad ibn Ibrahim who was the governor of Mecca, seeking him. Muhammad sent word to Sufyan asking if he wanted to come to them openly so he could be sent, or hide. Sufyan hid. Muhammad ibn Ibrahim sought him and commanded a herald to announce in Mecca: whoever brings Sufyan will receive such and such. He remained hidden in Mecca, appearing only to scholars and those who did not fear him.

narrators.name: Yahya ibn Abi Bukair
narrators.full_name: Yahya ibn Abi Bukair al-Kalbi

narrators.name: Shu'bah
narrators.full_name: Shu'bah ibn al-Hajjaj ibn al-Ward al-Ataki

chainIssues: Both narrators are highly reliable with direct transmission terms. Yahya ibn Abi Bukair heard directly from Shu'bah with 'samiʿtu' (I heard). This is a strong chain for a biographical narrative about Sufyan al-Thawri.

potential_issues.issue: The content is mostly biographical narrative about Sufyan al-Thawri rather than a hadith with explicit isnad to the Prophet ﷺ
potential_issues.impact: As a maqtu' (severed) transmission, this is a historical record of a scholar's life, not a prophetic tradition. The chain is reliable but the text is biographical.

Topics: Incident of Sufyan al-Thawri's ethical character regarding wealth and gifts
Sufyan's commercial dealings and distribution of profits to companions
Incident of the death of Sufyan's son and its impact
Incident of Sufyan hiding from the Abbasid authorities in Mecca
Authority's pursuit of Sufyan al-Thawri and his seclusion

english_translation: Narrated from Abd al-Rahman ibn Ishaq, from Said ibn Sulaiman, from Abu Shihab al-Hannat, who said: Sufyan al-Thawri's sister sent with me a bag containing cookies and sweets to Sufyan who was in Mecca. When I arrived in Mecca, I asked about him and was told he usually sits behind the Ka'ba near the entrance of the spice merchants. I found him there reclining. When I greeted him, he did not return my greeting as he normally did. When I told him his sister sent him food that was worth nothing, he sat up and talked to me. I said: Abu Abdullah, I came as your friend, greeted you, and you did not return my greeting properly. But when I told you about cookies worth nothing, you sat and talked to me. He said: O Abu Shihab, do not blame me, for these three days I have not tasted anything. I excused him. They said: When Sufyan feared in Mecca from being sought, he went to Basra. When he arrived, he stayed near Yahya ibn Sa'id al-Qattan. He asked the neighbors if any hadith scholars lived nearby. They said yes, Yahya ibn Sa'id. He said: Bring him to me. When Yahya came, Sufyan said: I have been here six or seven days. Yahya moved him to his quarter and opened a door between them. He brought the hadith scholars of Basra to greet him and learn from him. Among those who visited him were Jarir ibn Hazim, al-Mubarak ibn Fadala, Hammad ibn Salama, Marhumm al-Attar, Hammad ibn Zayd, and others. Abd al-Rahman ibn Mahdi came and accompanied him. Yahya and Abd al-Rahman used to write from him during those days. They spoke to Abu Awana to visit him but he refused, saying: How can I visit a man who does not know me? This was because Abu Awana greeted Sufyan in Mecca but Sufyan did not return his greeting. When asked about this, Sufyan said: I do not know him. When Sufyan feared that his staying near Yahya ibn Sa'id would become known, he asked Yahya to move him. Yahya moved him to the house of al-Haitham ibn Mansur al-A'raji from Banu Sa'd ibn Zayd Manah ibn Tamim. When Hammad ibn Zayd spoke to him about abandoning the authorities, saying this is the way of the people of bid'ah and what do you fear from them, Sufyan and Hammad agreed to go to Baghdad. Sufyan wrote to al-Mahdi or to Ya'qub ibn Dawud, beginning with himself, but was told they would be angry, so he began with them. He received a reply with courtesy, honor, and obedience. He was about to go to them when he fell ill with a severe fever and death approached. He was afraid, but Marhumm ibn Abd al-Aziz said to him: O Abu Abdullah, why this fear? You are going to your Lord whom you used to worship. He calmed down. He said: Look who from our Kufan companions is here. They sent to Abbadan. Abd al-Rahman ibn Abd al-Malik ibn Abjar and al-Hasan ibn Ayyash, brother of Abi Bakr ibn Ayyash, came to him. He entrusted to Abd al-Rahman ibn Abd al-Malik and asked him to pray over him. They stayed with him until he died. His funeral was brought out to the people of Basra suddenly. They heard of his death. A large crowd attended. Abd al-Rahman ibn Abd al-Malik prayed over him. He was a righteous man approved by Sufyan for himself. He descended into his grave with him and Khalid ibn al-Harith and others descended. They buried him. Then Abd al-Rahman ibn Abd al-Malik and al-Hasan ibn Ayyash went to Kufa and informed its people of the death of Sufyan, may Allah have mercy on him.

narrators.name: Abd al-Rahman ibn Ishaq
narrators.full_name: Abd al-Rahman ibn Ishaq ibn Ibrahim al-Wasiti

narrators.name: Said ibn Sulaiman
narrators.full_name: Said ibn Sulaiman al-Qurashi

potential_issues.issue: Use of 'an' (from) in the chain creates some ambiguity in transmission
potential_issues.impact: While 'an' is acceptable from generally reliable narrators like these Saduqs, it introduces slight uncertainty about direct hearing. This is minor given the biographical context.

english_translation: The name of Salih is Haya ibn Salih ibn Muslim ibn Hayyan ibn Shafi ibn Hunayy ibn Rafi ibn Qumali ibn Amr ibn Mata ibn Sahlan ibn Zayd ibn Thawur ibn Malik ibn Mu'awiyah ibn Duman ibn Bakil ibn Jashm from Hamadan, and his kunya is Abu Muhammad. Al-Fadl ibn Dukain informed us, saying: Ali and Hasan the sons of Salih are twins, born in one womb, and Ali preceded him by an hour. I never heard Hasan call him by his name; he used to say: Abu Muhammad (said this). Muhammad ibn Sa'd said: Ali was a reader of the Qur'an. Ubaydullah ibn Musa said: I read the Qur'an to him. Ali died in the year one hundred and fifty-four in the caliphate of Abi Ja'far, and he was trustworthy (thiqah). Hisham ibn Muhammad said: The mother of Ali and Hasan the sons of Salih ibn Haya is Umm al-Aysar daughter of al-Miqdham ibn Muslim ibn Hayyan ibn Shufi ibn Hunayy ibn Rafi ibn Qamali, and she was trustworthy, God willing, with few hadiths. And his brother...

english_translation: He is Salih ibn Salih, and Hasan's kunya is Abu Abdullah, and he was an ascetic, worshipper and jurist. Al-Fadl ibn Dukain informed us, saying: I never saw al-Hasan ibn Hayyan sitting cross-legged. He said: A beggar came to him one day and asked him, and he took off his socks and gave them. He said: I saw him on Friday, and he disappeared on Sunday night. He disappeared for seven years until he died in the year one hundred and sixty-seven, hiding in Kufa, and over it at that time was Ruh ibn Hatim ibn Qabisah ibn al-Muhallab as governor for al-Mahdi. He said: And al-Hasan ibn Hayyan was a Shi'a supporter, and he married off the daughter of Isa ibn Zayd ibn Ali to him, and he hid with him in one place in Kufa, until Isa ibn Zayd died in hiding. Al-Mahdi sought both of them and was diligent in seeking them, but could not catch them until they died. Al-Hasan ibn Hayyan died six months after Isa ibn Zayd. He said: I heard Abu Nai'm al-Fadl ibn Dukain saying: I saw Hasan ibn Salih on Friday, attending it with the people, then he disappeared on Sunday, until he died, and at that time he was sixty-two or sixty-three years old, and he was trustworthy, sound in hadith, prolific in transmission, and a Shi'a supporter.

narrators.name: Al-Fadl ibn Dukain
narrators.full_name: Al-Fadl ibn Dukain Abu Uthman al-Kufi

But who would dare to say to Muhammad ibn Talhah that you lie? He was among those of high status, and he was...

He was trustworthy, reliable, steadfast, trustworthy, and prolific in hadith.

chainIssues: Amr ibn Khalid al-Misri is Saduq, which is moderately reliable. He reports direct hearing from Said ibn Mansur regarding praise of Zuhayr ibn Mu'awiyah. The chain is reasonably reliable for biographical transmission.

potential_issues.issue: Amr ibn Khalid al-Misri is Saduq, not among the highest grades
potential_issues.impact: While Saduq is generally acceptable, this is lower than Thiqah. The content is biographical praise rather than hadith transmission.

english_translation: Mawla (client/freed slave) of Banu Tamim, and his origin was from Basra, and he was a tutor (educator) for the children of Dawud ibn Ali ibn Abdullah ibn Abbas, and he died in Baghdad in the year one hundred and sixty-four in the caliphate of al-Mahdi, and was buried in the cemetery of al-Khizran, and he was trustworthy, prolific in hadith.

english_translation: From the descendants of al-Harith ibn Qays who became Muslim, and he had nine wives, so the Prophet ﷺ commanded him to keep from them four, and to separate from the rest. And Qays's kunya is Abu Muhammad. He said: And it was said to Qays: al-Hawwal, due to the abundance of his hearing and knowledge. And Qays died in Kufa in the year one hundred and sixty-eight at the end of the caliphate of al-Mahdi.

narrators.name: Qays ibn al-Rabi'
narrators.full_name: Qays ibn al-Rabi' al-Asadi (descended from al-Harith ibn Qays)

chainIssues: This is a biographical entry providing genealogical connection to a companion (al-Harith ibn Qays), details about his reputation (al-Hawwal - the one who changes, due to extensive learning), and death date.

potential_issues.issue: Biographical entry with reference to companion Qur'anic incident
potential_issues.impact: The entry references an incident from the Prophet ﷺ regarding al-Harith ibn Qays and his marriages, which is relevant historical context but this is biographical narrative rather than prophetic hadith.
